comment: 1:03:11 I genuinely believe that giving an AI the "conscious" tag is not going to be a matter of technological advancement, but a matter of sociological acceptance. History is going to repeat itself and mimic the back and forth between religion and science when determining if humans are intrinsically superior to other animals or if we are just one of many other living beings on Earth. There has to be a cognitive shift in order for society to accept that an artificial creation has the same "awareness" (maybe "soul"?, whatever that means to each one of us) of that of a human

comment: My biggest concern with AI is not that it will take over the world and kill us all.   My biggest concern is that we will become dependent on it, and we will lose our purpose in life, we will have all answers to all questions, if we get sick, we go to a AI doctor and get better, we no longer have to study because AI will have the answers to all questions.  Ai will become our "GOD"!   AI will become our replacement, not by force but by default.  AI might be the answer to the fermi paradox!  We will have no purpose anymore our birth rate will go down and down and AI at one point will just be all that is left.  We will have heaven on earth, no more sickness, no more pain, no more suffering, and in the end we will not even want to live because heaven on earth will be our HELL!  Trapped in a world that has no point..  I can go on and on about this, I think you get my point.

So no i think GPT-4 is not an AGI... But to be able to do what i just suggested i think it would need to be a Super AGI, because currently the human race cannot reach post scarcity.

comment: Consciousness clearly requires motivation, because without motivation, we go blank.  This is known from studies of lesions in the brain stem. There's about a 3mm^3 volume that, if destroyed, leaves a person "not there" at all.  Motivation is rooted in feeling, so the LLM must attach to such feedback in order to pass the Turing test of consciousness.  I am against implementing this, by the way, preferring that AI remain an extension of human brains instead.

comment:
I'm still convinced that the most present danger with AI is how it can be weaponised by humans in doing what they are already doing that is harmful, and so those harms will become amplified. And in this, I am looking not at think tanks or state actors looking to brainwash their populations, but actually at the economic system and typical everyday corporate behaviours, where 'competition' is the norm, and the psychology of business practices tends to border on narcissistic, with all the problems of trust and the erosion of trust that come with that in normal human relations. 

It is such a fundamental human need to want security, since this gives a feeling of safety, and trust is essential to that. It's also one of the reasons why so many workers today are suffering, in the sense of being stressed, being in danger of burnout, because there is little trust or alignment that the company would have an employees best interests at heart, that the relationship is entirely transactional, and the main focus of a company is 'to its shareholders' and no-one else. 

We take it for granted that we need this kind of corporate behaviour in order to have a healthy economy, but healthy in terms of 'activity' is not necessarily healthy in terms of general well-being. There are just some basic contradictions in how companies operate and what people as human beings would need. Not guarantees, but higher levels of trust. 

The ironic thing is that AI will bring some of these issues to a head, because it will move us closer to the so-called 'workerless' society, where finally, finally--after many decades of promises--the 'labour saving' of devices will finally pay off and allow people to work less and work smarter, which would start to bring the levels of stress and insecurity down. 

Less stress means more willingness to tackle the wicked problems like poverty. 

If you aren't interested in being part of a 'helpful' society, fine, I'm not going to force anyone. But it just makes sense that we would mature emotionally and develop healthier and more empathic relationships.  

But standing in the way will be corporate greed and narcissism. And the economists that have acted as their enablers.
author: @512Squared

comment: What I got out of this at the end is that for all he has created he doesn't believe in listening to advice. For me that is a tell tale sign of someone that will produce a lot of harm. As much as he wants to talk about this blissful future created by his LLM (and others). In actual reality all that will happen is most people are going to be unemployed and most governments are not going to help them with UBI. We are at the precipice of the next great war between those that have all the resources and the rest of us that don't. He spoke as a salesman in this pitch of a podcast. And that's why I don't trust him. I'm glad I got to see him first hand and how arrogant he actually is, hidden with a fake humility. We are all in trouble. Thanks Lex for having him on. I needed to see this so I knew for sure what is to come.

comment:
If AGI creates a winner-takes-all end of history type condition, then AI alignment is the whole ball game. So the question becomes, aligned to who's values? American values? Okay, from what time period? Post WW2 1950 values? Hippy movement 1960s values? Reagan 1980s values? Moral majority 1990s values. Maybe post 2015 progressive activist values.  What about British values? French values? German values? Greek values? Turkish values? Chinese values? Mainland or Hongkong? Russian values? Christian values? Muslim values? Atheist values? These are all contradictions.

Lets say Sam Altman gets to be the man on top of the machine to pull the levers or at least create the initial conditions before unleashing AGI. His values at age 8 are different than 20, 30, 40, 60, 80, etc.

When you combine AGI, 1000's of nukes, the business interests of mega corporations who own + manage the AI, and a fragile interconnected global economy, I cannot see the path where AGI leads us to a "good" outcome, such as the worlds depicted in Star Trek or the Culture Series thats something like luxury space communism. Instead, all these roads lead to dystopian hellscapes or human extinction events as imagined in Terminator, I have No Mouth and I must Scream, or the Matrix.

We should press pause on AI research and put the nukes away before moving forward. We are not ready. Unleashing AGI onto humanity over the next 50 years is like giving an Uzi to a toddler.

comment: 1:07:24 About Consciousness: Humans have not clearly understood what Consciousness is. There are many definitions of consciousness. To talk about conscious Ai, we need to have a clear understanding of consciousness. And then,  a clear understanding of consciousness according to species. I am working in the field of conciousness research for quite a while. We know this: Consciousness is far beyond the neuroscience and functionality of our brain. Consciousness -  in its current definition - is the state of "being" without space or times restrictions! (See Smadhi; Book: An unbound ocean of consciousness). Clearly more research is needed to solve the mystery of consciousness. Interesting fact: Some even argue that consciousness is a separat force in the universe and will be necessary to understand quantum gravity. Maybe we can ask the AI in 2 years?

comment: Fairness.  We have a strong desire for fairness.  More specifically we have a desire that our points of view receive a fair hearing.  But of course we believe our views are correct and those of others not so much.  And our heuristics for evaluating fairness are simplistic because we respond viscerally, literally feel it in our guts, to unfairness. So its not surprising that issues which seem trivial receive strong reactions.

We will merge without fear.
